reporting_cycle: Secretary-General reports every 3 months and an interim report for a three-month review
summary:
The Security Council adopted Resolution 1433 (2002) on 15 August 2002, 
Reaffirming resolutions 696 (1991) and 1268 (1999) on the situation in Angola, 
The Council emphasizes its commitment to preserving Angola's unity, sovereignty, and territorial integrity. 
It reaffirms the importance of the “Acordos de Paz”, the Lusaka Protocol, and the Memorandum of Understanding Addendum. 
The Council welcomes the Secretary-General's report of 26 July 2002 and expresses appreciation for the work of the United Nations Office in Angola (UNOA).

The Council authorizes the establishment of the United Nations Mission in Angola (UNMA) for six months until 15 February 2003. 
The mission aims to pursue objectives and perform tasks recommended by the Secretary-General.

A resident Special Representative of the Secretary-General (SRSG) will head UNMA and oversee a coordinated approach to United Nations activities in Angola.

The UNMA mandate includes: 
- Assisting parties in concluding the Lusaka Protocol by chairing the Joint Commission and leading the completion of pending tasks.
- Assisting the Government of Angola in tasks such as protection and promotion of human rights, mine action, humanitarian assistance, demobilized reintegration, economic recovery, and election preparation.

The Council requests the Secretary-General to report when the Joint Commission confirms completion of Lusaka Protocol tasks and provide an interim report for a three-month review of UNMA's work. 
The Council decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
